colonized the whole world,

585.46.text: which we are embarrassed about right now,

they had to define ways to indoctrinate

779.65.text:
The hero’s journey is a story pattern,
it is called a monomyth.

786.77.text:
This was invited by Joseph Campbell
and his book “The hero’s journey”.

793.17.text:
His idea was that in any decent
story, it is one pattern.

799.59.text:
You have the hero, he meets the mentor
and he gets the call for adventure.

808.86.text:
At first the hero resists the call,
then the hero goes on the journey

815.88.text:
Then there is the princess,
the love interest.

819.45.text: Then there is the father figure.

822.25.text:
You can already tell
that this is the plot of Star Wars.

825.57.text:
It is also the plot
of the Matrix, the Lion King

829.06.text: and a lot of film and TV stories.

833.87.text: The reason for that is that they copy it.

Joseph Campbell
was talking to the creators of Star Wars

that annoys writers,
thinkers and people who consume culture.

that you see again and again.

The fact that it is a man

capitalism is just a story.

1853.54.text:
Patriarchy and white supremacy
are just stories,

1857.23.text:
they are great organizing myths
that define our societies and futures.

1864.63.text:
there is the start
of a huge rewriting on the way.

1868.75.text: We can only become what we can imagine.

1871.97.text:
Right now our imagination
is being stretched in new ways

1875.16.text:
and we are learning as a culture
that heroes aren’t always white guys

1879.40.text:
and learning that life and love,
villainy and victory

1884.52.text:
Depending on who is telling the story
this is a good thing.

1888.83.text:
It's not easy and it's not over yet.
Nobody said it was gonna be easy.

1893.38.text:
Changing the world is never easy
it takes courage.

1896.91.text:
That's something
that I learned from Harry Potter.

1910.40.text:
Does anybody have
any question or comments?

1925.43.text:
Just ask me about Star Trek,
doesn't have to be a smart one.

1930.39.text:
I accept all stupid questions,
this is fandom!

1941.28.text: It is a question about Star Trek.

1943.24.text:
When Klingons are kinky
are they having gentle sex?

1959.05.text: Did you just speak Klingon? – A bit.

1965.66.text:
when they have kinky sex,
is it just gentle?

1971.09.text: That is such a lovely idea.

1976.12.text:
If I was a fanfic editor,
I would commission that.

1980.06.text:
The stuff that's been done with Klingons
was interesting lately.

1985.10.text:
Even with the transition
between the original series

1990.09.text:
Do you remember that episode
when they go back in time and meet

1994.83.text:
the horrible racist stereotype people
made to look like scary Arabs?

2003.26.text: This is what Klingons were meant to be.

2005.86.text:
And then Woof who is the Klingon hero
of The Next Generation

2010.37.text: looks at him and says: “What happened?”

2012.86.text: And he is like: “We do not speak of it”.

2015.39.text: That is how they explained that one.

2019.47.text:
Yes, this is very embarrassing.
Let’s not speak of it again.

2030.11.text:
I read an article from you
about female robots.

2034.46.text:
I watched Ex-Machina
and future vision movies lately.

2041.90.text:
What do you think
about femininity in future visions?

2051.12.text: What do I think about female robots?

2053.24.text:
I have a lot of thoughts
about female robots.

2059.30.text:
People have always written stories
right from Metropolis on.

2067.80.text:
Almost a hundred years long
people have been writing stories

2075.61.text: It is this interesting fictional mode.

2081.29.text:
From long before we had a capacity
to make AI,

2085.26.text:
we’ve been imagining robots
doing basic work for us.

2092.46.text: The clue is in the name.

2095.26.text:
Robot derives
from the Czech word for "slave".

2100.23.text:
Right through from Metropolis
to Battlestar Galactica we had this

2107.28.text:
the writer Katherine Cross calls this
“a guilty memory of the future”.

2115.84.text:
we gonna exploit them
and what’s that gonna look like?

2119.00.text: I think it's not an accident

2121.09.text:
that we imagine these creatures
to be women.

2126.86.text:
It’s not about working out
whether robots are human

2131.96.text: but working out whether women are human.

2136.31.text:
The story is always the same,
it comes up in comics and so on.

2141.48.text:
The story is that young, shy,
sexually frustrated man

2148.22.text:
meets Robot Girl
and goes through this emotional process

2154.24.text: trying to decide “Is she really human?

2156.73.text:
Can I really love her?
Can she love me back?

2159.16.text:
Is it okay to have sex with her?
Maybe it’s okay?”

2162.92.text:
It’s not the story of this guy
trying to figure out

2165.94.text: whether the robot is a human

2167.63.text:
but actually a story about guys
figuring out whether women are human.

2170.93.text: If you are a woman who dates men,

2174.41.text:
then you can watch this
happening in real life.

2182.23.text:
I don't know if any woman
who dates in this audience...

2188.74.text:
Has anybody ever been told
after a couple of dates with any guy:

2193.45.text:
“You are just different
from all the other girls”.

2198.27.text: Has anybody been ever told that?

2200.42.text:
Yes? It’s the same thing!
It’s like:

2202.57.text:
“I’ve realized you are a human being.
I can really talk to you.”

2207.21.text:
"Thank you, you’ve just insulted
like half my friends.”

2211.23.text: It is meant to be a compliment:

2213.04.text:
“You are not like all these other women,
you are an actual human being”.

2222.60.text:
in an oppressed sex class
is an identity challenge to men.

2229.29.text:
I think, that is one of the things
that is being worked out.

2232.66.text:
Our expectations of technology
shape our expectations of the future.

2238.94.text: They shape our expectations of gender.

2241.77.text: It is both interesting and worrying

2244.60.text:
that a lot of the AIs we are designing
are female.

2248.47.text:
When I say “we”
I mean mostly dudes are designing.

2254.15.text:
Siri’s default setting is female,
Cortana, Alexa.

2258.30.text:
Tay, a terrible experiment
of Microsoft on Twitter.

2266.09.text: She was meant to be a happy teenage girl,

2269.62.text:
then you are making sex bots,
making fembots.

2274.84.text:
People are comfortable designing
a creature to serve, doing it for free.

2285.15.text:
They are more comfortable designing
that creature as female.

2288.41.text:
If they designed it as male they
would have to treat it like a person.

2317.02.text:
What is your thought
on how studios portray characters

2326.23.text:
that are put in other races or genders,
when this is put in the movie?

2332.93.text:
Maybe the story
was about an Asian character

2336.03.text: and they cast the generic white guy.

2342.28.text:
What was the hashtag
that was trending yesterday?

2346.99.text:
Anybody know the hashtag
trending on Twitter?

2354.72.text:
About Asian people
not seeing themselves...

2361.72.text:
Asian people not seeing
themselves represented on screen,

2364.99.text:
because even stories taken from Anime,
Asian stories

2371.83.text:
and Hollywood
recasting them as white characters.

2376.72.text: There is clearly somebody in the studio,

2381.21.text:
saying: "Nobody wants to watch a movie
with all Asian characters".

2388.51.text:
"Nobody watches anime,
nobody likes that stuff.

2397.84.text:
So we will just cast Scarlett Johansson
in everything.

2400.43.text:
I don’t have a problem
with Scarlett Johansson.

2402.73.text:
But I also think
somebody else should get to play robots.

2410.47.text:
Scarlett Johansson
is playing all the robots,

2413.06.text:
all the characters
that we’re wondering if they are human.

2416.60.text:
Also the new "Ghost in the Shell"
it’s always Scarlett Johansson.

2422.90.text:
We seem to be having a crisis
about Scarlett Johansson.

2430.22.text:
Somebody has actually made
a Scarlett Johansson robot.

2433.91.text:
A real one that they can have sex with
and marry.

2436.96.text:
I would really like to know
what Scarlett Johansson thinks about it.

2449.57.text:
In the name of making money,
of pushing back

2459.15.text:
on the changing culture and stories,
this is happening.

2462.88.text:
I don’t see any way this can be positive.
It makes the people sick.

2472.17.text:
I think studio producers still see
white as default anybody can relate to.

2483.96.text: Any deviation from that is a challenge.

2490.71.text:
It means, it is a threat
and people won’t go to see it.

2496.73.text:
They think everybody wants to
relate to these characters.

2499.37.text:
The idea that white people
could relate to Asian characters

2502.31.text: is beyond the pale which is nonsense.

2505.79.text:
But one thing that I think
is interesting and good:

2511.66.text:
the idea of the lowest common thing
as culture becomes more diverse,

2517.22.text:
as the internet becomes
more powerful and important

2520.40.text:
in shaping culture and in shaping
how these stories are produced.

2524.62.text:
A lot of TV is watched over Netflix
and other services.

2530.17.text:
That idea of box-office,
lowest common denominator

2534.33.text:
is becoming less important
in terms of how monomyths are created.

2541.56.text:
You don’t now have to make a product
that will appeal to everyone.

2550.20.text:
You can find your audience
all over the world,

2553.11.text: they can tune in at a different time.

2556.24.text:
A show like for all its problems,
and it has many racist problem,

2563.09.text:
like the "Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt",
which is feminist but also quite racist.

2572.15.text:
Even that was considered
too radical for primetime TV.

2576.64.text:
It was then commissioned
and put up by Netflix,

2579.40.text:
Netflix has picked up
a lot of shows like this.

2584.04.text:
Shows like "Orange is the new black",
“Orphan Black”,

2587.67.text:
they have a life online which they
could not have at the box-office.

2592.50.text:
This is why movies
are becoming less and less important.

2597.60.text:
I think the narrative TV is the form
of narrative of this moment.

2608.70.text:
You were talking about
the hero's journey.

2618.45.text:
I totally agree that it’s an advantage
to have female, black, Asian characters.

2624.97.text:
But how would you imagine
to change the story of a hero's journey?

2629.41.text: How to change the hero's journey?

2632.69.text:
One of the things
about the hero's journey itself is:

2639.41.text:
If you tell the same story over
and over again it’s boring.

2644.35.text:
One of the things
that are unusual right now in cultures:

2650.10.text:
People are realizing that more diversity
in culture and story-telling

2654.41.text:
is not just good
because it is more diverse.

2658.37.text:
People aren’t just going to
see these things because of that.

2664.74.text:
These are better stories
because they haven't been told yet.

2669.34.text:
They are just better.
They are more fun.

2675.42.text:
Somebody else loves Mad Max!
I love it, too!

2678.95.text: Things like that and people saying:

2681.13.text:
“Don’t see the story,
it’s too entertaining.

2685.04.text:
People might or might not go
because of the diversity element

2690.68.text:
but these stories are popular
because they are original.

2697.28.text: They have got new heroes, new problems,

2700.21.text:
problems people are having
for many years and generations

2705.95.text:
that haven’t been told
in the public narrative in the same way.

2712.16.text:
If the hero’s journey
gonna have an afterlife,

2716.35.text:
it’s gonna be in things like Star Wars
where they just recast it.

2722.03.text:
That is the things with
the hero's journey right now.

2725.64.text:
If you look at the hero’s journey
it is very precise like

2734.55.text:
and by chapter five the hero
must be gone on an adventure”.

2742.30.text:
One of the stories
that hits it page for page,

2749.44.text:
The first Hunger Games book.
It’s just the hero’s journey.

2754.79.text:
Nobody notices this
because it seems so original

2760.39.text: because it is about a powerful girl.

2762.26.text:
Girls aren’t meant to be heroes
in that way.

2766.10.text:
That is so shocking,
even though it is a hero's journey again

2774.06.text:
because they imagine a woman,
not a basic strong female character,

2780.10.text:
but a hero with flaws
that overcomes the monomyth.

2787.76.text:
I love the "Hunger Games",
I didn’t get to talk about it much today.

2791.81.text:
That is the reason why it is
so interesting and powerful.

2803.29.text:
I am very interested in your answer
to the big Star Wars fan question:

2821.27.text: You know what it is? - Yeah of course.

2830.68.text:
It is important, because she is a woman
and a main character.

2835.81.text:
Female main characters
have to be allowed to have flaws.

2839.24.text:
Not just
to be perfect incarnations of fanfiction.

2846.62.text:
Is everybody familiar
with the Mary Sue characters?

2850.80.text:
A Mary Sue is a concept
that developed within fanfiction.

2857.76.text: You know when you write Harry Potter

2859.79.text:
and there is the exciting new character
that is both a vampire and a witch

2864.09.text:
who gets to have sex
with Harry and Draco.

2867.34.text:
And everybody loves her.
That’s the Mary Sue.

2870.51.text: Generally a Mary Sue has no flaws.

2873.23.text:
The criticism of Rey
is that she is a Mary Sue character.

2884.27.text:
Yeah, Rey is a character
who is heroic and badass.

2887.63.text:
She has all these amazing skills,
how did she pick those up?

2891.98.text: But the idea is the recognition,

2896.03.text:
that this
is a fan coded retelling of Star Wars.

2900.75.text:
A Mary Sue is meant to be
an interruption in the story.

2908.07.text:
It is not a real character,
it is an upstart character.

2912.54.text:
A woman who is perfect
has no place in the story.

2920.23.text:
I mean Daredevil is a Mary Sue,
Batman is a Mary Sue.

2925.12.text:
So many male characters
are Mary Sue or what is it?

2930.84.text:
That is the version,
somebody reminded me of that.

2935.55.text:
All these characters
are the self-insert perfect character.

2942.78.text:
It is not criticized when it is a dude,
because dudes are meant to do all that.

2946.84.text:
I think Rey is a boring character
because she doesn’t have any flaws.

2950.84.text:
Katniss is different,
because she is frightened all the time,

2955.09.text:
she is stubborn
and nobody really likes her.

2957.93.text:
That’s what makes her
an interesting character.

2960.14.text:
Whereas they were too nervous
to give Rey any flaws.

2967.09.text: She is a fighting girl and that’s it.

2969.15.text:
But Star Wars
is never going to be massively radical.

2978.59.text:
Hi, maybe that is a dumb question:
What is your favorite ship?

2987.36.text:
My favorite ship
was always Remus and Tonks

2995.22.text:
This was kind of disappointing
because I was into it before.

2999.81.text: But that was back in the day.

3005.78.text:
Thank goodness most of my fanfiction
I wrote and was involved in was on paper.

3014.10.text: I’m very glad about that right now.

3018.11.text:
I went back to my parent's house
and I found my old Buffy fanfic.

3026.59.text:
That was so amazing.
She was such a Mary Sue character.

3030.42.text:
She was an amazing vampire woman
who was English and short.

3035.77.text:
She got to have sex with everyone.
And she was also a witch.

3041.50.text: That was so good but really embarrassing.

3046.89.text: Apart from that I couldn't choose.

3053.14.text:
One more question?
– One more question and we’re done.

3062.56.text:
I forgot my actual question.
But back to the Marty Stew thing.

3067.70.text: If you think about Luke Skywalker

3069.78.text:
it is clearly a self-insert character
for George Lucas.

3073.27.text:
I read something by Mark Hamill
who played Skywalker

3082.86.text: and he behaved like George Lukas would.

3087.53.text: And he got the part perfectly.

3092.16.text:
That is so adorable.
That makes so much sense.

3097.56.text:
Are we done or should we have
one more question?

3111.41.text: I have a Harry Potter question.

3114.42.text:
I heard people talking about
the sexual orientation of Dumbledore.

3119.90.text: What do you think about it?

3124.54.text:
Is it a homophobic thing,
that him being gay is a scandal

3132.91.text:
but people don’t talk about
the sexual orientation of anybody else?

3140.97.text: Do you think it is homophobic?

3145.64.text:
I don’t think
it is necessarily homophobic.

3148.76.text:
The interesting thing about Harry Potter
is that there is no sex in it at all.

3154.50.text:
Remus and Tonks presumably have sex
because she is pregnant in the end,

3159.76.text: but it is not ever mentioned.

3166.83.text:
because that is how Young Adult Fiction
is written.

3169.40.text:
With Dumbledore a wife is not mentioned,
though a lot of wives are mentioned.

3174.67.text:
Then J.K. Rowling comes
and says in one interview

3178.43.text:
that she always imagined
Dumbledore as gay.

3182.64.text:
The reaction to that was like:
"Wow, this is such a scandal."

3187.64.text:
Actually it made sense to the people
writing and reading fanfiction.

3192.03.text: It made sense to a lot of people

3194.11.text:
who had imagined different versions
of those characters for ages.

3199.81.text:
J.K. Rowling is an interesting writer
in terms of how she engages with fans.

3208.31.text: With the casting of Hermione as black,

3213.06.text:
when she was writing that book
in the 90s,

3217.32.text:
was she imagining
a young black British girl as Hermione?

3224.71.text:
But she understands that fiction
is more important than that.

3231.26.text:
Books can function in a broader way
than just one writer’s version of it.

3239.18.text:
She tweeted massive support for this,
Rowling loves black Hermione.

3244.74.text:
Of course that made people
even more upset.

3247.80.text:
Revealing that she’d
imagined Dumbledore as gay

3251.78.text: was really exciting to a lot of readers.

3255.21.text:
There are no openly gay characters
in Harry Potter.

3260.98.text:
People have different ideas
about the Kenneth Brennan character

3265.36.text: in the second book and movie.

3272.03.text:
There are no openly gay characters
and this is a way of rectifying that

3276.16.text:
because culture has moved so far
since that book was being written.

3281.28.text: It is a way of keeping it relevant.

3305.29.text:
Wir haben jetzt
eine kurze Umbaupause von 15 Minuten.

3308.08.text:
Eine Nachricht
möchte ich noch durchgeben.

3311.34.text:
Gestern stand einer erst im Stau,
dann hat er seinen Flug verpasst.

3314.70.text:
Jetzt hat er den bekommen
und wird heute um 11:30 hier auftreten.

3321.49.text:
Allerdings nicht wie gestern vorgesehen
eine ganze, sondern eine halbe Stunde.

3325.17.text:
Thomas Fischer,
der Richter, der wird hier sein.

3328.49.text:
Er spricht über Strafrecht,
Wahrheit und Kommunikation.

3335.32.text:
Jetzt haben wir eine kurze Pause
und sehen uns in 15 Minuten.
